department: Department of Chemical Engineering and Applied Chemistry
application_procedure:
Please complete the TA Application here:https://tams.fase.utoronto.ca/TamsPortal/postings/che 
If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact ugradassist.chemeng@utoronto.ca
duties: Assist course instructor with the delivery of undergraduate labs including but not limited to supervising students work in a lab environment, demonstrating the use of lab equipment and techniques, communicating clearly and effectively in terms of expectations, evaluating laboratory student performance, ensuring a safe and effective learning environment; keeping clear records of student grades and communicating these to students appropriately and consistent with UofT guidelines. Assist in the set-up of certain experiments and/or demonstrations and clean-up of assigned teaching area and common lab areas.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates should be enrolled or should have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies, University of Toronto with strong written and oral communication skills, strong laboratory skills, clear understanding of laboratory safety, experience working safely in an experimental chemistry laboratory and a demonstrated commitment to teaching. Candidates should have strong foundational knowledge of organic and inorganic chemistry, instrumental analysis (IR, GC), and organic chemistry techniques (TLC, melting point apparatus, distillation, liquid-liquid extraction). Candidate should hold a bachelor's degree in Chemical Engineering, Chemistry, or Engineering Chemistry. Preference will be given to those with a background in Chemical Engineering due to the alignment with the course objectives and content.
qualifications_preferred: Previous experience with microscale equipment and in a teaching lab environment would be an asset.
salery: $53.92 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

job_title: Italian Culture Through Food - Head TA
application_procedure: Applicants should send the requested documents below to the attention of Prof. Arsalan Kahnemuyipour, Chair, Department of Language Studies, UTM via email to jobslanguagestudies.utm@utoronto.ca by the posted deadline: 1. DLS Unit 1 Job Application form (Please submit your information here: https://forms.office.com/r/94cuaqRR5T, then "print to PDF" to save a copy of the submission), 2. Cover letter (this should include a statement on the applicant's background and experience with respect to the posted qualifications), and 3. Current academic CV.
duties: Assist course instructor with TA management and course administration, mentor and provide feedback to other TAs. (NOTE: The mode of instruction for this course is expected to be online synchronous. However, if this changes for any reason, as much advance notice as practicable will be given.)
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Demonstrated ability in the specific area of the course (gastronomy, history, cultural studies, diaspora studies, experiential learning) is required. Native, or near-native, fluency in written and spoken Italian is required.
qualifications_preferred: Graduate-level research in Italian studies is preferred. Experience in this course or a similar course is preferred.
salery: $52.97/hour + vacation pay.  Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure: Apply here: https://cupeha.utm.utoronto.ca/dept/ummgt/app/instr
duties: The duties of Course Instructors shall include the normal duties associated with the design and teaching of university degree credit courses or sections of courses. These include the preparation and delivery of course content, including lectures and/or seminars; creation of course ware; the development/administration of assignments, tests and examinations; the marking/grading of student work and the submission of grades to appropriate University officials in accordance with policy; the maintenance of reasonable hours of student contact outside of scheduled contact hours; and the supervision of the day-to-day work of any Sessional Instructional Assistants or Teaching Assistants assigned to the course.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Course Instructors are expected to be of superior teaching ability, with suitable academic and/or professional qualifications, currency and mastery of the subject matter. Successful applicants will have clearly demonstrated teaching excellence in the subject matter through previous experience teaching the course in question, or very similar courses.
qualifications_preferred: Successful applicants will typically have significant experience in applying the subject matter in a practical environment.

job_title: Math and Stats Support- Head TA
application_procedure: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/dept/ctl/app/ta
duties:
Duties may include: assisting the coordinator with organizing and facilitating TA training sessions; meeting periodically with the MSS Coordinator; holding in-person and virtual office hours for CTL’s Math and Statistics Support program; helping students with their calculus courses; delivering workshops and exam review seminars in-person and in an online setting; providing virtual one-to-one sessions; responding to student queries by email and Quercus Forum discussions; filming educational materials, if there is a student demand for it; and helping with MSS initiatives and promotion such as U(t)-Mathazine and Math in Action Journal. For Fall 2025 and Winter 2026, some duties will be completed on campus. Teaching assistants should also have access to a stable, high-speed internet line, a computer with a working webcam and microphone and a quiet workspace.

Appointment Dates: September 2, 2025 to April 30, 2026
Weekly Scheduled Hours: To be arranged.
To complete the application, please upload:
1. Cover Letter (indicate student status (eg. first year of M. Sc program) at the beginning of the term in the Cover Letter)
2. CV or Resume
3. Transcript (Unofficial is acceptable)
4. Names and contact information of THREE references.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: A successful applicant has a minimum Master's Degree in Math. Solid knowledge of Calculus courses in undergraduate programs at the University of Toronto, Scarborough campus is a requirement. Applicants should have excellent communication skills and a minimum of 3 years of teaching experience or TA experience in the field of Mathematics; demonstrated experience leading and facilitating TA meetings is required.
qualifications_preferred: A solid understanding of CTL's Math and Stats Support Program and previous MSS TA experience will be an asset . Experience conducting and holding review seminars and workshops would be an asset. An average grade of A- in four C or D level math courses and familiarity with web conferencing tools such as Microsoft Teams and Zoom would be an asset.
salery:
January 1, 2025 : Undergraduate (UG)/SGS I/SGS II/PDF: $52.97 per hour
January 1, 2026: Undergraduate (UG)/SGS I/SGS II/PDF: $53.92 per hour

job_title: Introduction to Linguistics: The Sounds of Language
application_procedure: Applications should be made with an academic CV and cover letter via the TAships website (https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/lin) by the posted deadline. In your application, please include a statement on your background and experience with respect to the posted qualifications. Please also list all previous Unit 1 positions held.
duties: Grading of assessments and teaching of weekly tutorials. Other responsibilities are as assigned by the instructor and may include: course orientation, weekly preparation, lecture attendance, meetings with the instructor, communication with students, and invigilation of the final exam. Note: The mode of instruction for this course is expected to be in-person. However, if this changes for any reason, as much advance notice as practicable will be given.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Demonstrated ability in the specific areas of the course (phonetics, phonology, morphophonology from a theoretical linguistic perspective) is required.
qualifications_preferred: Graduate-level research in theoretical linguistics is preferred. Graduate-level research in the specific subject area of this course is preferred. Experience in this course or a similar course is preferred.
tutorial: Mondays at various times (Please see ttb.utoronto.ca)  [NOTE: The mode of instruction of these tutorials is expected to be in-person. However, if this changes for any reason, as much advance notice as practicable will be given.]

department: Department of Leadership, Higher & Adult Education

duties: Assist course instructor with the delivery of undergraduate labs including but not limited to supervising students work in a lab environment, demonstrating the use of lab equipment and techniques, communicating clearly and effectively in terms of expectations, evaluating laboratory student performance, ensuring a safe and effective learning environment; keeping clear records of student grades and communicating these to students appropriately and consistent with UofT guidelines. Assist in the set-up of certain experiments and/or demonstrations and clean-up of assigned teaching area and common lab areas.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates should be enrolled or should have made application to be enrolled in the School of Graduate Studies, University of Toronto with strong written and oral communication skills, strong laboratory skills, clear understanding of laboratory safety, experience working safely in an experimental chemistry laboratory and a demonstrated commitment to teaching. Candidates should have strong foundational knowledge of inorganic chemistry, instrumental analysis (IC, ICP, UV-Vis), and analytical chemistry techniques (titration, dilutions, error analysis, mass and volume measurements using analytical equipment and volumetric glassware). Candidate should hold a bachelor's degree in Chemical Engineering, Chemistry, or Engineering Chemistry. Preference will be given to those with a background in Chemical Engineering due to the alignment with the course objectives and content.
qualifications_preferred: Previous experience working in an analytical lab and in a teaching lab environment would be an asset.
salery: $52.97 per hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

duties: Must be available in-person at least 2 days (ideally 3-4 days) per week during regular business/working hours for practicals/labs/tutorials/lectures/office hours. Teaching Assistants must be available evenings and weekends (online) when assigned to manage the discussion boards, especially close to assessment deadlines. Teaching Assistants will need to run and manage labs/practicals/tutorials, office hours, and even assist/support instructors in teaching lectures in-person at UTM. Should be comfortable generating CSC108 related content and questions for assessments (including tests and examinations) and for extra-help problems. Lab TAs and Lecture TAs are expected to adequately prepare before each lab or lecture session. All TAs will be responsible for grading which will occur on evenings, weekends, and during business hours. Prompt completion of grading with tight turnaround times (within the specifications of the Collective Agreement, and as discussed with the course coordinator), is essential to the operation of this course and is a requirement for this role.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Experience coding in the Python programming language (writing multi-function and multi-file programs; building unittests, doctests, and pytests). Expertise with the CSC108 content, CSC148 content, and beyond. Strong grades in a minimum of 3.0 FCEs of CSC courses from UTM, including at least 1.0 FCEs of systems courses. Note that CSC-like courses offered in different departments do not count towards the FCE requirement as the courses offered in other departments or in other campuses differ widely in content, coverage, or expectations. Able to effectively run and manage labs/practicals/tutorials/lectures, mark assessments (labs, assignments, tests, exams), hold office hours, respond to emails and discussion boards (including responding to technical questions) and effectively manage and answer questions on the course discussion board. Demonstrated record of commitment to teaching pedagogy and student learning. Demonstrated record of timeliness in communication and carrying out duties, and demonstrates promptness and reliability in all responsibilities. Excellent organizational skills and strong written & spoken English communication skills. A demonstrated and consistent ability to complete work on time and communicate in a timely manner. High level of attention to detail. Familiarity with the undergraduate UTM experience and with the UTM computing environment in MCS.
qualifications_preferred: N/A

Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required: 
o	Strong communication skills and ability to communicate statistical concepts to beginner statistics students
o	Experienced in using R, R-studio to produce plots, data summaries, and perform basic statistical tests
o	Experience in interpreting statistical results in plain English 
o	Available to lead weekly in-person tutorials on Fridays at the scheduled time
o	Available to attend six 2-hour in-person teaching team meetings during the term (tentatively to be held on Wednesdays, time TBD)
qualifications_preferred:
Preferred: 
o	Experience developing tutorial materials, evaluation rubrics, and materials to support the development of student writing and speaking skills is or a demonstrated interest to develop such skills
tutorial:
Meeting Schedule: 	Lecture:	https://ttb.utoronto.ca/ (tentative) 
Tutorials:	FR:09:00-11:00

application_procedure: https://utapcsc.utm.utoronto.ca
duties: Leading weekly labs and attending TA meetings. Grading assignments and exams. Recording grades. Possibly holding office hours or monitoring the online discussion board, answering emails etc. Tutorial/lab TAs are expected to adequately prepare before each session.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Advanced machine learning knowledge and experience with large datasets.  Interested applicants must contact the course instructor (email with subject [TA-CSC490]). Able to effectively run and manage labs/practicals/tutorials/lectures, mark assessments (labs, assignments, tests, exams), hold office hours, respond to emails, and effectively manage and answer questions on the course discussion board. Demonstrated record of commitment to teaching pedagogy and student learning. Demonstrated record of timeliness in communication and carrying out duties. Excellent organizational skills and strong written & spoken English communication skills. A demonstrated and consistent ability to complete work on time and communicate in a timely manner. High level of attention to detail. Familiarity with the undergraduate UTM experience and with the UTM computing environment.
qualifications_preferred: N/A

job_title: Introduction to the Theory of Computation (Writing Development Initiative)
application_procedure: https://utapcsc.utm.utoronto.ca
duties: Assessing the writing quality of second-year student assignments, and providing quality feedback to help students improve their writing. There will be a (remote) benchmarking meeting prior to grading each assignment, and TAs must be available to attend these meetings. Remote applicants are welcome, but we will need to be able to schedule these benchmarking sessions.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants must have a strong grasp of written English and academic writing in the sciences, and be able to identify issues in student writing. Applicants must have an interest in academic writing in computer science.
qualifications_preferred: N/A

application_procedure: https://utapmat.utm.utoronto.ca/utap/
duties: Will include some of the following: running tutorials, marking, invigilation, office hours, preparatory work, and other duties of administering the course.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Strong grades in a minimum of 3.0 FCEs of mathematics courses, including at least 1.0 FCEs of primarily proof-based courses. Note that "MAT-like" courses offered in different departments do not count towards the FCE requirement as they do not adhere to the standards of rigour used in mathematics courses. In the alternative, applicants whose portfolio includes at least 2.0 FCEs of MAT specialist classes will be deemed to have satisfied the FCE requirement. The candidate must have strong grades and demonstrated knowledge of the course content and beyond; have a demonstrated record of commitment to teaching pedagogy and student learning; have a demonstrated record of timeliness in communication and carrying out duties; and possess excellent communication skills and professionalism.
qualifications_preferred: Teaching experience preferred

application_procedure: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/dept/ctl/app/ta
duties:
Duties may include: holding in-person and virtual office hours for CTL’s Math and Statistics Support program; helping students with their calculus courses; delivering workshops and exam review seminars in-person and in an online setting; providing virtual one-to-one sessions; responding to student queries by email and Quercus Forum discussions; filming educational materials, if there is a student demand for it; and helping with MSS initiatives and promotion such as U(t)-Mathazine and Math in Action Journal. For Fall 2025 and Winter 2026, some duties will be completed on campus. Teaching assistants should also have access to a stable, high-speed internet line, a computer with a working webcam and microphone and a quiet workspace.

Appointment Dates: September 2, 2025 to December 23, 2025 or September 2, 2025 to April 30, 2026
Weekly Scheduled Hours: To be arranged.
To complete the application, please upload:
1. Cover Letter (indicate student status (eg. first year of M. Sc program) at the beginning of the term in the Cover Letter)
2. CV or Resume
3. Transcript (Unofficial is acceptable)
4. Names and contact information of THREE references.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: A successful applicant has solid knowledge of Calculus courses in undergraduate programs at the University of Toronto, Scarborough campus. Applicants with excellent communication skills and a minimum 1-2 years of teaching experience or TA experience in the field of Mathematics.
qualifications_preferred: An average grade of A- in four C or D level math courses and familiarity with web conferencing tools such as Microsoft Teams and Zoom would be an asset.
salery:
January 1, 2025 : Undergraduate (UG)/SGS I/SGS II/PDF: $52.97 per hour
January 1, 2026: Undergraduate (UG)/SGS I/SGS II/PDF: $53.92 per hour

application_procedure: https://www.utsc.utoronto.ca/webapps/cupehiring/dept/ctl/app/ta
duties:
Duties may include: holding in-person and virtual office hours for CTL’s Math and Statistics Support program; helping students with their statistics courses; delivering workshops and exam review seminars in person and in an online setting; providing virtual one-to-one sessions; responding to student queries by email and Quercus Forum discussions; filming educational materials, if there is a student demand for it; and helping with MSS initiatives and promotion such as U(t)-Mathazine and Math in Action Journal; and providing consultations for graduate students and faculty members with their research data. Duties may be delivered remotely/online or in person. For Fall 2025 and Winter 2026, some duties will be completed on campus. Teaching assistants should also have access to a stable, high-speed internet line, a computer with a working webcam and microphone and a quiet workspace.

Appointment Dates: September 2, 2025 to December 23, 2025 or September 2, 2025 to April 30, 2026
Weekly Scheduled Hours: To be arranged.

To complete the application, please upload the following documents:
1. Cover Letter (please indicate student status in the cover letter (eg. Yr 1 of M. Sc program) at the start of the term)
2. CV or Resume
3. Transcript (unofficial copy is accepted)
4. Name and Contact Information of THREE references
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Solid knowledge of Statistics courses in undergraduate programs at the University of Toronto, Scarborough campus; excellent communication skills; and 1-2 years of teaching experience or TA experience in the field of Statistics.
qualifications_preferred: Proficiency of statistical software such as R and familiarity with web conferencing tools such as Teams and Zoom would be an asset.

January 1, 2025 : Undergraduate (UG)/SGS I/SGS II/PDF: $52.97 per hour

job_title: Mathematics Concepts for Elementary Teacher Candidates
application_procedure: Please apply via https://hiring.oise.utoronto.ca/
duties:
CTL7100 MathPlus is a mandatory non-credit math course for Master of Teaching candidates enrolled in the Primary/Junior or Junior/Intermediate division. This course is not about math pedagogy or theory, but rather its purpose is to deepen the math content knowledge of teacher candidates (e.g., improving their skills in multi-digit multiplication, division, order of operations, fractions, decimals, percentages, ratios, integers, exponents, manipulating expressions and solving algebraic equations) and improve their math confidence.

Duties include: 24 hours of face to face teaching time, 12 two-hour classes throughout the fall-winter academic year, tracking homework completion, marking performance assessments, offering math content support to TCs when required, and attending three MathPlus meetings throughout the year. This course is delivered in-person during daytime hours.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Applicants must possess a strong knowledge of Grades 6 to 8 mathematics. Currency and mastery of the subject area are important. Candidates will be considered for multiple sections and we ask that you indicate if you are available to TA multiple sections in your cover letter.
qualifications_preferred: Preference will be given to candidates who have had successful experience with teaching mathematics to adult learners and learners with low math confidence.
salery: Fall 2025: $52.97 hourly plus applicable vacation pay; Winter 2026: $53.92 hourly plus applicable

duties: The primary duty for this position is virtual office hour support for students.  TA's will set up online booking links and share them with the Research 1 Instructor team. TAs will familiarize themselves closely with the Research 1 course syllabus and assignment guidelines. They will meet with the TA supervisor at the start of the position and as requested over the course of the year. TAs will provide students with guidance in developing literature reviews (searching, citing, synthesizing, making meaning of the lit, researcher positionality). TAs will also facilitate two sessions of the annual MT Research Conference.  The TAs are expected to familiarize themselves closely with the literature review assignment expectations and evaluation instruments so that they can provide accurate and supportive guidance. Duties may also include preparing and/or reviewing resources to support students in their literature reviews.
experience: The need to acquire experience is the more relevant criterion than previous experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Candidates should possess experience writing literature reviews and have experience conducting qualitative research. They should have a demonstrated commitment to researcher reflexivity, positionality, and critical citation practice. Candidates are expected to have experience teaching and/or supporting academic writing and experience with research design and qualitative research methods. Candidates should possess strong organizational and communication skills (oral and written), and have experience providing substantive and specific feedback on student work. Experience with academic coaching and writing support would be considered a strong asset.  Demonstrated knowledge and practice of equity, diversity and inclusion required. An Ontario Teaching Certificate is an asset.
qualifications_preferred: Candidates should possess experience writing literature reviews and have experience conducting qualitative research. They should have a demonstrated commitment to researcher reflexivity and critical citation practice. Candidates are expected to have experience teaching and/or supporting academic writing and experience with research design and qualitative research methods. Candidates should possess strong organizational and communication skills (oral and written), and have experience providing substantive and specific feedback on student work. Experience with academic coaching would be considered a strong asset.  Demonstrated knowledge and practice of equity, diversity and inclusion required. An Ontario Teaching Certificate is an asset.

application_procedure: Please apply via https://hiring.oise.utoronto.ca/
duties: Working as a member of a team of graduate students to: Offer one-to-one advising appointments to all OISE graduate students including teacher education students who require assistance with their oral and written communication skills in the following areas; academic writing (planning, organizing, writing and revising academic papers such as essays, MRPs, theses, dissertations, manuscripts for publication, funding applications, lesson plans, portfolios, personal journal entries); presentation skills (in-class presentations, conference presentations, lesson delivery); Provide support to teacher candidates in developing teacher skills (lesson planning process, mock lesson feedback) and developing strategies to meet the diverse needs of learners; In conjunction with the annual Professional Preparation Conference, provide support for teacher education students preparing for job applications and interviews; Provide individualized support for international students and new Canadians with their English language development (grammar, oral communication, listening, reading and pronunciation skills; Support international students and new Canadians in acculturating to the university environment; Support internationally educated teacher candidates to become familiar with the culture of Canadian K-12 schools; Promote the services of the OISE Student Success Centre to faculty members and students; Use the online appointment booking and tracking software to post summaries of appointments; Attend and contribute to regular team meetings.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: This position requires a high level of proficiency in English, strong communication and writing skills, strong interpersonal skills, as well as experience working with English language learners. Teaching experience is not mandatory but will be considered a significant asset in supporting some components of the OSSC's mandate and OISE students. You must be able to work well independently and as part of a team, create a learning climate of mutual respect and fairness, understand, develop, and provide a learning environment that supports diversity and inclusion. Many OSSC activities take place online and all advisors must be able to perform online appointments using the OSSC's online system. Therefore, it is expected that advisors have technological equipment with internet capabilities.
qualifications_preferred: Priority will be given to OISE doctoral students. Previous experience working in a university writing centre or teaching academic writing/skills courses.
salery: Fall 2025: $52.97 hourly plus applicable vacation pay; Winter 2026: $53.92 hourly plus applicable

duties:
Your duties will include any or all of the following: supporting students' understanding of statistics concepts related to their coursework and exam preparation and to report and record hours worked and activities in log provided by lead Teaching Assistant. 
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required:
o	Current MSc or PhD student in the Department of Statistical Sciences or in biostatistics
o	Available to hold office hours in-person at the same time each week for all 12 +/- 1 week in the fall term and for all 12 +/- 1 week in the winter term
o	Available to hold office hours in-person during the exam period (Fall: Dec. 3-22, Winter: April 7-28) 
o	Experience in diverse undergraduate courses in statistics (as a student or as a TA)
o	Able to communicate complex statistical ideas with diverse students
qualifications_preferred:
Preferred:
o	Proficient in R/R Markdown and/or Python
o	Experience in debugging in R

						Winter 2026: UG/SGS I/II - $53.92/hour (+4% vacation)

job_title: An Introduction to Statistical Reasoning and Data Science
application_procedure:
Application information is available at https://www.statistics.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cupe-positions-unit-1. The deadline to submit your application is July 18, 2025. For more information, you may contact:
Angela Niazmand
Undergraduate and TA Administrator
Department of Statistical Sciences
University of Toronto
700 University Avenue
Ontario Power Building - 9160-6
Toronto, ON M5G 1Z5
www.statistics.utoronto.ca
E-mail: jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca
duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:

Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, leading training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required:

o	Strong communication skills and ability to communicate statistical concepts to beginner statistics students
o	Experience in interpreting statistical results in plain English 
o	Experienced in using R, R-studio to produce plots, data summaries, and perform basic statistical tests
o	Experience developing tutorial materials, evaluation rubrics, and materials to support the development of student writing and speaking skills is an asset.
o	Must be available for teaching team meetings 5-6 times each term (two 2-hour sessions each day). The first two meetings will be in the first two weeks of the semester, and the others will be scheduled with the course instructor at a later date
o	Must be available during scheduled tutorial times on Fridays
qualifications_preferred:
Required:

o	Strong communication skills and ability to communicate statistical concepts to beginner statistics students
o	Experience in interpreting statistical results in plain English 
o	Experienced in using R, R-studio to produce plots, data summaries, and perform basic statistical tests
o	Experience developing tutorial materials, evaluation rubrics, and materials to support the development of student writing and speaking skills is an asset.
o	Must be available for teaching team meetings 5-6 times each term (two 2-hour sessions each day). The first two meetings will be in the first two weeks of the semester, and the others will be scheduled with the course instructor at a later date
o	Must be available during scheduled tutorial times on Fridays
salery:
Fall 2025: $52.97/hour (+4% vacation pay)
Winter 2026: $53.92/hour (+4% vacation pay)

job_title: Wizard Managers of Risks: Exploring Actuarial Science
application_procedure:
Application information is available at https://www.statistics.utoronto.ca/employment-opportunities/cupe-positions-unit-1. The deadline to submit your application is July 18, 2025. For more information, you may contact:
Angela Niazmand
Undergraduate and TA Administrator
Department of Statistical Sciences
University of Toronto
700 University Avenue
Ontario Power Building - 9160-6
Toronto, ON M5G 1Z5
www.statistics.utoronto.ca
E-mail: jobapps.statistics@utoronto.ca
duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:
Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required: 
o	4th year undergraduate student in the Actuarial Science program (major or SPE) or graduate student with undergraduate actuarial science background
o	Successful completion of the following courses: ACT240, ACT245, ACT247, ACT351 or equivalent OR passed at least two SOA exams
qualifications_preferred:
Preferred:
o	Available during course meeting times
tutorial:
Meeting Schedule: 	Lecture:	Thursday: 3 PM – 5 PM (tentative)
			Tutorials:	N/A

For detailed information on the application procedure go to:
https://cupeha.utm.utoronto.ca/dept/umpsy/app/ta
duties: Marking/grading; contact hours with students; preparation; test invigilating; Quercus uploading of files and grades; leading tutorials if indicated.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: At least a 4-year degree in Psychology with appropriate background for the course to be demonstrated.
qualifications_preferred: Previous experience in teaching a similar course is highly desirable.
tutorial: (Please see ttb.utoronto.ca) [NOTE: The mode of instruction is expected to be in-person. However, if this changes for any reason, you will be provided with as much advance notice as practicable.]

duties:
Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.

Duties
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:

Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required: 
o	Strong communication skills and ability to communicate statistical concepts to beginner statistics students
o	Experience in interpreting statistical results in plain English
o	Experienced in using R, R-studio to produce plots, data summaries, and perform basic statistical tests
o	Available for TA meetings 5-6 times each term (two 2-hour sessions each meeting day, tentatively scheduled for Wednesdays). The first two meetings will be in the first two weeks of the semester, and the others will be scheduled with the course instructor at a later date.
o	Available during scheduled tutorial times on Fridays
qualifications_preferred:
Preferred: 
o	Experience developing tutorial materials, evaluation rubrics, and materials to support the development of student writing and speaking skills is or a demonstrated interest to develop such skills
tutorial:
Meeting Schedule: 	Lecture:	MO:09:00-11:00 (tentative)
			Tutorials:	FR:09:00-11:00 (tentative)

application_procedure: All applications for this round to be submitted online at https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/lin.  Please do not submit applications by email.  Contact linguistics@utoronto.ca if you have any questions.
duties: The Course Instructor position involves the normal duties related to the design, teaching, and timely administration of a university credit course, including but not restricted to (i) preparation and delivery of course content, (ii) development, administration and marking of assignments, tests and exams, (iii) calculation and submission of grades, (iv) holding regular office hours, (iv) supervision of TAs or Graders as required. Please consult the Arts & Science timetable to confirm the times and modality of the course.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: he successful candidate will hold ASLTA or ASL Instructor certification (or equivalent) and have knowledge of Deaf culture and/or lived experience with a Deaf community. Documentation of native or near-native fluency in ASL is required; scores should be submitted from an ASL Language Proficiency Interview (ASLPI) or other assessment conducted by a qualified organization (e.g. the Canadian Cultural Society of the Deaf, Gallaudet University, or the ASLTA). Evidence of prior successful teaching of ASL must be submitted along with the application (teaching evaluations, sample syllabi, etc.).
qualifications_preferred: A Master's or PhD in a relevant field is preferred. Previous experience working with Teaching Assistants/Graders is desirable. Excellent teaching evaluations and relevant active research are an asset. At least two semesters of experience working in the Department of Linguistics at UofT is an asset.

salery:

o	Must demonstrate to have successfully completed a senior undergraduate course in regression analysis covering course topics or equivalent
o	Experience in conducting linear regression analysis, including assessment and correction of assumptions and appropriate model diagnostics
o	Experience performing statistical analyses and data manipulation in R and R-Studio
o	Strong organizational skills and ability to maintain tactful communication with students
qualifications_preferred:
Preferred: 
o	Experience in report writing and statistical communication
o	Experience providing written and formative feedback to others or a demonstrated interest to develop such skills
o	Familiarity with scientific report structure and best practices
o	Experience answering a variety of student questions (e.g., debugging code, writing advice, writing proofs and problem solving, data analysis techniques)

Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:

Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.

experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required: 
o	Strong programming skills in R with experience using advanced visualization libraries (e.g., ggplot2, Shiny, Plotly) 
o	Strong skills and experience with data visualization  
o	Familiarity with course topics such as perception, graphic design, visualization principles, and data-driven communication 
o	Previous teaching experience in interactive, problem-solving tutorials and labs 
o	Confident in assessing written reports, verbal presentations, and group projects 
o	Available to participate in training sessions throughout the term with the course instructor
qualifications_preferred:
Preferred: 
o	Experience with a range of visualization software/libraries such as Tableau, VegaLite, D3.js, etc... 
o	Previous teaching experience in related course(s) (e.g., STA313, JSC270/JSC370, STA2555, CSC2537, CSC318), and/or professional experience in the relevant subject matter.  
o	Successful completion in advanced related course(s) (e.g., STA313, STA2555, CSC2537, HAD5014, INF451) 
o	Familiarity with research methods in Human-Computer Interaction (HCI)

duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:

Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required:
o	Academic background in Statistical Sciences. PhD student (or graduate) in actuarial science, statistics or biostatistics.
o	Proficient in programming in R
o	Proficiency/knowledge in most, if not all, of the course topics indicated below is preferred:
•	Programming in an interactive statistical environment.
•	Generating random variates and evaluating statistical methods by simulation.
•	Algorithms for linear models, maximum likelihood estimation, and Bayesian inference.
•	Statistical algorithms such as the Kalman filter and the EM algorithm.
•	Graphical display of data.
qualifications_preferred:
Required:
o	Academic background in Statistical Sciences. PhD student (or graduate) in actuarial science, statistics or biostatistics.
o	Proficient in programming in R
o	Proficiency/knowledge in most, if not all, of the course topics indicated below is preferred:
•	Programming in an interactive statistical environment.
•	Generating random variates and evaluating statistical methods by simulation.
•	Algorithms for linear models, maximum likelihood estimation, and Bayesian inference.
•	Statistical algorithms such as the Kalman filter and the EM algorithm.
•	Graphical display of data.

duties:

Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required: 
o	Strong communication skills and ability to communicate statistical concepts to beginner statistics students
o	Experience in interpreting statistical results in plain English
o	Experienced in using R, R-studio to produce plots, data summaries, and perform basic statistical tests
o	Available  for TA meetings 5-6 times each term (two 2-hour sessions each meeting day, tentatively scheduled for Wednesdays). The first two meetings will be in the first two weeks of the semester, and the others will be scheduled with the course instructor at a later date.
o	Available during scheduled tutorial times on Fridays
qualifications_preferred:
Preferred: 
o	Experience developing tutorial materials, evaluation rubrics, and materials to support the development of student writing and speaking skills is or a demonstrated interest to develop such skills

application_procedure:

duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:
Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
o	Experienced in R, R-studio, tidyverse in writing various simulations and interpret results, such as elementary bootstrapping, simulating sampling distributions, generating data, etc. 
o	Applicants must be available to lead weekly tutorials
o	Must demonstrate to have successfully completed this course or equivalent in introductory statistics for statistic majors
o	Good facilitation and presentation skills
o	Good oral and interpersonal skills, particularly able to show tact when communicating with students
qualifications_preferred:
o	Experienced in R, R-studio, tidyverse in writing various simulations and interpret results, such as elementary bootstrapping, simulating sampling distributions, generating data, etc. 
o	Applicants must be available to lead weekly tutorials
o	Must demonstrate to have successfully completed this course or equivalent in introductory statistics for statistic majors
o	Good facilitation and presentation skills
o	Good oral and interpersonal skills, particularly able to show tact when communicating with students

duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:
Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.
Duties of this position shall be performed on the St. George Campus.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required:
o	Undergraduate degree with Statistics Minor or Major and current graduate student in Statistics, Biostatistics, or related discipline
o	Experience with quantitative life science research and/or analysis and interpretation of resulting data (e.g., coursework and/or research)
o	Experience performing statistical analyses using R/R Markdown and ability to troubleshoot technical issues
o	Available to attend class meetings in-person for both LEC sections to support students on weeks with scheduled class activities such as labs
qualifications_preferred:
Preferred: 
o	PhD candidate in Statistics, Biostatistics, or related discipline
o	Experience answering a variety of student questions (e.g., debugging code, writing advise, data analyses) or a demonstrated interest to develop such skill
o	Experience providing written and formative feedback to students or a demonstrated interest to develop such skill
o	Ability to communicate, both verbally and in writing, with a diverse team in a clear and precise manner
o	Ability to assist students search for and understand relevant literature
o	Familiarity with scientific report structure, scientific writing, and best practices
o	Previous TA experience and professional development in teaching (e.g., TATP workshops)
o	Previous experience with STA288H1: Statistics and Scientific Inquiry in the Life Sciences

duties:
Duties are in person unless otherwise indicated and will include any or all of the following:

Preparation for classes, preparation of written or audio-visual materials, designing and maintaining course websites, attending lectures, running tutorial sessions, facilitating and evaluating student engagement on online discussion boards, participating in training sessions, meeting with the instructors, teaching, leading discussions, and supervising laboratories, rating students' work, holding office hours, consulting with students (including electronic consultation), writing and grading tests, examinations and lab sets, grading essays and term papers, invigilating midterm and final exams, setting up experiments, conducting field trips, and conferring with the supervisor in charge, as required by the employee's teaching duties.

experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum:
Required: 
o	Strong programming skills in R with experience using advanced visualization libraries (e.g., ggplot2, Shiny, Plotly) 
o	Strong skills and experience with data visualization  
o	Familiarity with course topics such as perception, graphic design, visualization principles, and data-driven communication 
o	Previous teaching experience in interactive, problem-solving tutorials and labs 
o	Confident in assessing written reports, verbal presentations, and group projects 
o	Available to participate in training sessions throughout the term with the course instructor
qualifications_preferred:
Preferred: 
o	Experience with a range of visualization software/libraries such as Tableau, VegaLite, D3.js, etc... 
o	Previous teaching experience in related course(s) (e.g., STA313, JSC270/JSC370, STA2555, CSC2537, CSC318), and/or professional experience in the relevant subject matter.  
o	Successful completion in advanced related course(s) (e.g., STA313, STA2555, CSC2537, HAD5014, INF451) 
o	Familiarity with research methods in Human-Computer Interaction (HCI)

Experience teaching or working as a TA in a business program or business communications program, a demonstrated commitment to best practices in pedagogy, and experience developing students' skills through similar initiatives to those listed above are assets.

application_procedure: If interested, please reply to: jobsmcs.utm@utoronto.ca  with the following information by July 31, 2025: 1) your current CV, including a clear description of your teaching experience; 2)your current status; your department; your research area; 3) the name and e-mail address of at least one reference who can comment on your teaching ability (optional)
duties: Responsible for all aspects of delivering a university credit course including: planning the lectures, tutorials, assignments and tests and marking schemes; providing appropriate contact time outside of class to students, through office hours, emails, etc.; invigilating the final exam; managing the grades and submitting the final course grades; dealing with student petitions, setting and grading a make-up exam if required.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Ph.D. in Mathematics, completed or nearly completed. Or current registered PDF in Mathematics. Advanced comprehension of the subject matter as evidenced by research activity and/or advanced teaching experience. Strong organizational, interpersonal, and communication skills.
qualifications_preferred: Demonstrated evidence of excellence in teaching preferred. Preference will be given to candidates with demonstrable currency and mastery.
salery: $9,276.01+ vacation ‬for half course (or $10,366.55+ vacation for half course for first-time CIs)

job_title: French Language Skills and Learning Strategies for University Study
application_procedure: Applications should send the requested documents below to the attention of Arsalan Kahnemuyipour, Chair, Department of Language Studies, UTM via email to jobslanguagestudies.utm@utoronto.ca by the posted deadline: 1. DLS Unit 1 Job Application form (Please submit your information here: https://forms.office.com/r/94cuaqRR5T, then "print to PDF" to save a copy of the submission), 2.Cover letter (this should include a statement onthe applicant's background and experience with respect to the posted qualifications), and 3.Current academic CV.
duties: Grading of assignments, tests, and the final exam, and teaching of weekly tutorials.  Other responsibilities are as assigned by the instructor and may include: course orientation, weekly preparation, weekly meetings with the instructor, and invigilation of the final exam. Note: The mode of instruction for this course is expected to be in-person. However, if this changes for any reason, as much advance notice as practicable will be given.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Ph.D student in French Studies, Education or other relevant discipline. (Near-)native written & spoken French is required.
qualifications_preferred: Demonstrated expertise teaching university-level French-as-a-second-language courses.  (Near-)native spoken English competence.  Experience with this or a similar course.
salery: $52.97/hour + vacation pay. Should rates stipulated in the Collective Agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the Collective Agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure: Apply online at: https://tapp.cs.toronto.edu/#/external/postings/ztciZ6DLnpj4ampJeT19KnxK    For inquiries, contact: tacoord@cs.toronto.edu. In your application you will be asked to respond to the following question(s): Based on the course description of this posting, please briefly describe how your academic history, and/or research and professional experience make you qualified for this position.
duties: All duties are in person unless otherwise indicated. Duties will be primarily marking, hosting group discussions, mentoring students on their research publication, and meeting/emailing with the professor for guidance and to get feedback. TA responsibilities involve giving feedback to three homeworks on writing research, which also have a peer-review component, taking attendance, and office hours (or communication) with students.  Note the duties start early – August 18, 2025 and ends October 31, 2025.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: see preferred qualifications
qualifications_preferred: The chosen candidate must be familiar with academic and scientific writing and have publication experience. Ideally, the incumbent will have knowledge and experience of writing and revising drafts of research papers, crafting research abstracts and titles, conducting literature reviews and experiments, creating figures and tables, presenting research (i.e. poster and oral presentations), and the submission and review process. The incumbent should demonstrate maturity and have strong English writing and oral communication/presentation skills. Previous TA experience is an asset.
tutorial: see the University's Timetable Builder for section times: https://ttb.utoronto.ca

application_procedure: Please go to: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/eng/postings
duties: Marking; course administration; office hours; other duties (as needed)
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Academic background in literary studies in English and in academic and/or creative writing. Preference will be given to applicants familiar with foundational courses in English and who demonstrate good prior knowledge of the subject-matter of the course (such as graduate courses; ongoing research at the graduate level; and/or previous TA experience in the area)
qualifications_preferred: N/A
salery: $53.92 per hour (+ vacation pay). Should rates stipulated in the collective agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the collective agreement shall prevail.

application_procedure: All individuals interested in this position must submit a cover letter and a CV, and be prepared to submit a sample syllabus if requested. The cover letter should succinctly highlight the applicant’s experience relevant to the course content. Submit  application materials via email to the Art History Graduate Administrator: graduate.arthistory@utoronto.ca. A valid return email address is required. Applications submitted after the job closing date will not be considered. Applications submitted by any method other than via email to the Art History Graduate Administrator will not be considered.
duties: All normal duties related to the design and teaching of a University-credit course, including: developing and publishing the syllabus and marking scheme through Quercus; preparing and delivering lectures and/or leading discussions during the 2 lecture hours each week (Mondays 3:00-5:00pm, in person); preparing relevant assignments for student assessment, and (if applicable) setting and invigilating term tests and the final assessment; marking of student work and reporting final grades to the university; maintaining office hours for academic counselling of students; and supervising a TA.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Completed PhD or current PhD candidate in Renaissance Art History; if the PhD is in progress, the qualifying exam must already have been passed. Demonstrated skill in teaching, writing, and communication in the history of art are required.
qualifications_preferred: Previous teaching experience and/or tutorial leadership in this or a similar course at the university level is preferred. Also preferred is experience with management and delivery of courses using University of Toronto or similar online systems (e.g., Quercus, Canvas-based technologies, Microsoft Teams, etc.).

duties: Teaching Assistants may expect to be involved in any of the following, as requested by the course coordinator: giving student tutorials or lectures; marking tests and assignments; assisting in making lecture materials and tests available to students; administering course evaluation surveys; available for student questions by e-mail; invigilating tests and final exams; sending reminders to lecturers and students about upcoming commitments; be present at the day of lecture to help with setup; maintaining the course Quercus page; preparing exam packages; contributing to marking mid-term and final exams or coordinating marking of exam questions with lecturers; hosting Q&A sessions for final exam preparation. The course will be delivered in-person.  If public health circumstances change at the university, Zoom or an equivalent, will be used to continue course delivery on-line.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: PhD student in biostatistics or statistics with a strong background on biostatistics; or in a health science discipline with strong background in biostatistics. Proficiency in R and RStudio required.

application_procedure:
Applicants should submit a cover letter and CV (via email) by July 20, 2025.  Applications should be sent to:

Dr. Ali Salahpour, Chair, Department of Pharmacology and Toxicology 
c/o Ms. Charlotte Pashley, Medical Science Building, 1 King’s College Circle, room 4207, Toronto, ON, M5S 1A8, charlotte.pashley@utoronto.ca

If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact:   charlotte.pashley@utoronto.ca.

The University strives to be an equitable and inclusive community, and proactively seeks to increase diversity among its community members. Our values regarding equity and diversity are linked with our unwavering commitment to excellence in the pursuit of our academic mission. The University is committed to the principles of the Accessibility for Ontarians with Disabilities Act (AODA). As such, we strive to make our recruitment, assessment and selection processes as accessible as possible and provide accommodations as required for applicants with disabilities. If you require any accommodations at any point during the application and hiring process, please contact uoft.careers@utoronto.ca. During employment, to request accommodation from the University, contact the supervisor or department chair and/or Health & Wellbeing Programs & Services at hwb@utoronto.ca. For more information about accommodations at U of T, please visit our Accommodation webpage.

The hiring criteria for Course Instructors positions are academic qualifications, the need to acquire experience, previous teaching experience and previous satisfactory employment under the provisions of this Collective Agreement.

The University of Toronto is strongly committed to diversity within its community and especially welcomes applications from racialized persons / persons of colour, women, Indigenous / Aboriginal People of North America, persons with disabilities, LGBTQ2S+ persons, and others who may contribute to the further diversification of ideas.

Candidates who are members of Indigenous, Black, racialized and LGBTQ2S+ communities, persons with disabilities, and other equity seeking groups are encouraged to apply, and their lived experience shall be taken into consideration as applicable to the position.

This job is posted in accordance with the CUPE 3902 Unit 1 Collective Agreement. 
The position(s) posted above is (are) tentative, pending final course determinations and enrolments.

Positions posted here are open to Graduate Students in the School of Graduate Studies, Postdoctoral Fellows and Undergraduate Students in the University of Toronto.

Note: Although a graduate student’s preference as to the campus location of his/her TA appointment will be taken into account, both the initial TA appointment (or CI appointment) and the subsequent appointment obligation related to that appointment may be met through position(s) on any one of the three University of Toronto campuses (UTM, UTSC or St. George) in courses in the same discipline as the initial appointment. TAs will only be assigned to courses in fields in which they are or should be qualified to assist. Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located. Where the duties are intended to be performed at another location, such other location will be specified in the posting.
duties:
The course instructor will assist 4th year life science teams with the laboratory aspects of their biotechnology projects. Student projects are student-designed and student-initiated. This year’s teams will work with hydrogels to create sensors of bacteria or to deliver enzymes. Another team will focus on nanopolymer antibody drug conjugates. Teams are 3-4 students from across different life science Departments. The course is JPM400Y: Biomedical Incubator Capstone Project.

Students will write draft experimental protocols and the course instructor will: (a) help students edit and revise their protocols, and (b) help operationalize student projects in the Department of Teaching Laboratories at the Medical Sciences Building.

The course instructor will instruct three student teams, at approximately 5 hours per week throughout the academic year, Friday 9 am to 2 pm.
experience: Past teaching experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: The successful applicant will be in the process of completing or have obtained a doctoral degree (PhD) with a specialization in the fields of biomedical engineering, chemistry, cell and molecular biology, biochemistry, pharmacology, toxicology, physiology, immunology or a related life science field. The individual will have demonstrated excellent knowledge and experience with laboratory (bench) science techniques and underlying theories. Previous teaching or mentoring experience in undergraduate education is an asset.
qualifications_preferred: Ideal applicants will have strengths in working with an equity, diversity, inclusion, Indigeneity and accessibility lens, and a strong interest in innovation and entrepreneurship. Direct experience with translational biomedical research is an asset. Demonstrated experience (through work or volunteer work) of effective facilitation of small-group discussions is an asset. Experience working in a team setting is valued, as is experience with project management of timelines and multiple parallel tasks. Strong candidates will demonstrate an open mind, curiosity, and adaptability to change, and will encourage and motivate life science students to maintain progress and productivity. Experience with ordering biochemical and chemical reagents is helpful. Previous experience as a TA within a practical course and/or with the Division of Teaching Labs (DTL) is preferred.

appointment_size: 163 hours for 3 positions; 120 hours for 2 positions
application_procedure: Applicants should submit a cover letter including the names of two references (preferably academic), an academic writing sample (essay, paper, or report), examples of teaching evaluations (if available), and CV to the UC TA Online application site at: https://taships.iit.artsci.utoronto.ca/uc/login by Friday 18 July 2025. If during the application and/or selection process you require accommodation due to a disability, please contact Khamla Sengthavy at Khamla.sengthavy@utoronto.ca or 416-978-8083.
duties: Conducting tutorials (5 in fall term and 5 in winter term). Meeting with instructor; responding to student inquiries (over email and virtual meetings); holding office hours; and marking papers, tests, exams and/or other assignments. Some attendance at lectures or other plenaries may be required. The delivery method for this course is currently in-person. Please note that, in keeping with public health advisories, the course delivery method may change as determined by the Faculty or the College. Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located. Final availability of the position(s) is contingent upon enrolment, budgetary considerations and the determination of appointments as governed by the collective agreement.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: At a minimum, a bachelor’s degree in Cognitive Science or cognate field (e.g. Computer Science, Linguistics, Philosophy, or Psychology).
qualifications_preferred: MA or Ph.D. student in Cognitive Science or cognate field (e.g. Computer Science, Linguistics, Philosophy, or Psychology) is preferred. Experience with theoretical argumentation and the use of empirical evidence in cognitive science is an asset. Demonstrated superior teaching expertise in undergraduate teaching is preferred.
salery: $52.97/hour (Fall 2025) and $53.92/hour (Winter 2026) plus 4% vacation pay (UG, SGSI, SGSII, PDF)

duties: Work with course instructor to prepare course materials and hold lab tutorials. Possible activities include: attending the lectures and lab sessions online; helping to create and updating in-class activities and exercises; performing demonstrations for the labs; developing computational infrastructure for student projects; helping with basic course materials. The delivery method for this course is currently in-person. Please note that, in keeping with public health advisories, the course delivery method may change as determined by the Faculty or the College. Duties of this position shall be performed at the campus on which the position is located. Final availability of the position(s) is contingent upon enrolment, budgetary considerations and the determination of appointments as governed by the collective agreement.
experience: Previous experience is the more relevant criterion than the need to acquire experience in respect of this posted position.
qualifications_minimum: Final-year or senior undergraduate students with official records of completion of no less than two Computer Science programming courses in Python (e.g., CSC108H1, CSC148H1) and two courses in Cognitive Science – one of these courses needs to be COG260H1. Demonstrated superior teaching expertise in undergraduate teaching is preferred. Knowledge of probability and statistics is highly desirable.
qualifications_preferred: Graduate students (Masters or Ph.D.) with official records of completion of no less than two Computer Science programming courses in Python (e.g., CSC108H1, CSC148H1) and two courses in Cognitive Science – one of these courses needs to be COG260H1. Demonstrated teaching expertise and superior undergraduate teaching is preferred. Knowledge of probability and statistics is highly desirable.
salery: $52.97/hour plus 4% vacation pay (UC, SGSI, SGSII, PDF)

They will be present in the lab during regularly scheduled lab periods to provide advice and guidance to students. TA support is also provided. Evaluation responsibilities include the grading of experimental work, participation in oral examinations at the end of the course and submission of grades to the Course Coordinator.

qualifications_preferred: Significant experience engaging with the U of T Advanced Undergraduate Lab. Experience contributing to experiment development or writing of manuals.
salery: $9,276.01 (plus vacation pay) [$10,366.55 (plus vacation pay) if this is the first CI appointment]

course_id: multiple courses offered in the GPLLM program
appointment_size: Hours of work are determined by the tests and examinations scheduled. As a result, minimum/maximum hours cannot be guaranteed
application_procedure:
Applicants must submit a cover letter and resume, clearly indicating any previous invigilation experience. University of Toronto student number and confirmation of registration status on ACORN is required. Confirmation of availability for the period outlined above is required. Applicants must also confirm availability to invigilate weekday evening and weekend examinations.
Applications should be addressed to the Assistant Dean, Graduate Programs and must be submitted by email to gpllm@utoronto.ca.
Please note that incomplete applications will not be considered.
duties:
Incumbents will supervise the writing of tests and examinations by students enrolled in the Global Professional Master of Laws (GPLLM) program at the Faculty of Law. Responsibilities include, but are not limited to, the following: distributing and collecting test and examination materials, verifying student identification, take attendance and collect student signatures at the start and end of the exam, escort students to and from washroom facilities, maintaining the integrity of tests and exams by adhering to departmental and university policies and procedures, monitoring test/exam time allotments, handling student concerns/problems that arise during exams and escalating any issues to the Assistant Director, GPLLM and/or Assistant Dean, Graduate Programs, documenting and responding to any unexpected situations that arise, gathering completed tests/exams and returning the exam questions and student papers to the program team, scanning handwritten exams for distribution to instructors, and maintaining required administrative records.
Hours of work are determined by the tests and examinations scheduled. As a result, minimum/maximum hours cannot be guaranteed. Most exams are written on evenings (e.g., 5:00 to 10:00 p.m.) and weekends (12:00 to 5:00 p.m.), and applicants are required to be able to accommodate invigilating exams that are held according to these schedules during both mid-term and final examination periods. See note below re: need to confirm availability to invigilate weekday evening and weekend exams at the time of application.
qualifications:
Applicants must be currently registered as students pursuing a degree at the University of Toronto and must continue to be registered as students throughout the duration of the appointment (thereby maintaining their eligibility for CUPE 3902 Unit 1 work). Any status change must be communicated to the GPLLM program immediately, so that eligibility to continue in the appointment can be determined. This is an on-campus, in-person position. Applicants must be available for in-person invigilation shifts that take place in the evening and on weekends. Experience invigilating tests and exams is strongly preferred. Applicants must demonstrate a commitment to the principles of equity and inclusion.
Skills (listed alphabetically): Ability to manage and resolve difficult or sensitive situations effectively while maintaining boundaries, attention to detail and an ability to follow instructions closely, ability to demonstrate integrity and professionalism while remaining calm under pressure, conflict resolution, advanced communication skills (both oral and written), initiative, interpersonal, organizational, problem solving and resourcefulness, attention to detail, situational awareness and the ability to manage changing priorities, understanding of and the
ability to apply relevant university policies, procedures and legislation, ability to collaborate with others and work in a team setting.
salery: $34.22 + $1/hour worked on Saturday and Sunday shifts + 4% vacation pay. Please note that should rates stipulated in the collective agreement vary from rates stated in this posting, the rates stated in the collective agreement shall prevail.
